glyph.desc: HPL uses a plus-like and sign to represent the conjunction "and".

body.p:
Astronomical
Observations
Made
By
H.P. Lovecraft,
598, Angell St.,
Providence,
R.I.
U.S.A.
Years:
1909
1910
1911
1912
1913
1914
1915
Comet, Halleys, ObservedObsd May 26, 1910 p. 1
Comet, Delavans, ObservedObsd SeptemberSep 16, 1914 p. 7
Eclipse of - June 3, 1909 p. a.
Eclipse of - MarchMar 11-12 , 1914 p . 6
Halley's Comet - May 26, 1910, p. 1
Halo around , FebruaryFeb. 1, 1912 p 3.
Mars, Occultation of, ObservedObsd SeptemberSeptr 1, 1909 p . 1
Moon, Eclipse of - June 3 -, 1909 p. a.
Moon, Halo around, FebruaryFeb. 1, 1912 p. 3
Mercury near Moon - FebruaryFeb. 26, 1914 pp . 5-6
Occultation of Mars - Kuala LumpurSeptemberSep 1 -, 1909 p. 1
Paraselenae - Lunar Halo - FebruaryFeb 1 -, 1912 p. 3.
a.

Special Observation
June 3 - 1909
Moons Eclipse
Clouds interfered, but several
glimpses were obtained -
Total 7.58 -

ASTRONOMICAL
OBSERVATIONS
Begun SeptemberSeptr. 1, 1909

SeptemberSeptr 1 - ObservedObs. Occultation of
Mars by Moons bright limb at
8h 58m occultation took 40s.
Ending at 9:57 was not observedobsd.
Shy hazy. Moon fair. ObservedObs MareM. HumorumHum. CleomedesCleom. LangrenusLangr.

Septr. 2 - ObservedObs. Mars at 9h. Markings
faint + ill defined. Also observedobs. Moon
MareM. Humorum appears similar to a
section bitten out of the moons
terminator.

ThursdayThu., May 26 ObservedObs. Halleys
Comet 8.45-9.30 p.m.
Visible in west. Head about
1.5mag. (slightly less brilliant
than Regulus) . Tail broad
May 26, 1910, Continued

+ well defined. Quite bright
for about 15, distinctly
traceable about 30 (to a
point above crater.).
Head about 9h 30m R.A.
3 decl. on border of Hydra
+ Sextans. Nucleus + Coma
well defined. Used B+SGgf. verweist "B+S" auf den Hersteller des Fernglases (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barr_and_Stroud). Unwahrscheinlicher: Verweis auf die Barrett-Serviss-Planisphre, vgl. Aufzhlung der Instrumente am Ende des Notizbuchs.
prism binoculars, powerpr. 8.

Regulus
Hydra
Position at 9 p.m.
ObservedObs. from Providence-Taunton PikeVmtl. die heutige US44 zw. Providence und Taunton (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Route_44#Massachusetts)
at a point just northeastN.WE. from Nichols
CrossingVmtl. diese Kreuzung: https://maps.app.goo.gl/R1M9gbk2RM6WTS5Q8 Vgl. https://www.town.rehoboth.ma.us/sites/g/files/vyhlif4911/f/uploads/rehoboth_historic_sites_booklet.pdf. Looking westward
Head of Comet

Evtl. liegt eine Verwechslung mit vor.
Position of Head
in Hydra
No observations

FebruaryFebr. 1st. ObservedObservd a lunar halo
at about 6:30 p.m. Moon 1dayd. of full
Halo was of about 45 diameter,
with rather noticeable paraselenae
on an horizontal line with the
moon. No prismatic colours
were apparent. The left hand
(northern) paraselena was
more or lesless obscuredobscurd by clouds
and appearedappeard only at intervals.
The right-hand mock-moon
was prominent, and attracted
much attention. The two
paraselenae were seen as
diffuseddiffusd patches of light.

This part of halo most prominent .
NorthN.
Paraselena
(faint + visible
only at intervals)
Moon
SouthS.
Paraselena
(Prominent -
attracted much attention )
Clouds
EASTERN HORIZON

The northern arc of the halo
was by far the brightest part.

OctoberOctr. 19, 11:00p.m. ObservedObs. Moon, 2daysd. gibbousgibs.
Copernicus on terminator.
Tycho, Clavius + Maginus were
favourably situate in the
southern part of the disc.
No observations

In January, Mars + Saturn were
observed.

FebruaryFeb. 26, 6:h 15m p.m. ObservedObs. Moon, 2daysd. old,
and Mercury.
Moon's crescent very thin. Earthshine
visible even in strong twilight.
Mercury appeared about 5 below and to
the right of Moon, twinkling like a
bright star in the increasing
dusk.
R.A. 23h 56m Dec +1
R.A. 23h 35m Dec -0 3'
The above position very rough.

The Moon was almost at the
Vernal Equinox.

Mercury
View looking northwestN.W.
Earlier in the day the Moon
and Mercury had been in
conjunction.

March 11-12 ObservedObs. partial
eclipse of Moon. Over 0.9 of disc
eclipsed. Very well seen.

SeptemberSeptr. 16 - 4 a.m. to dawn -
ObservedObs. Delavans Comet
+heavens in general.
Delavans Comet lay in R.A.
10h 08m 06s., Dec. 49 51' 14"
in Ursa Major, as shown by diagram.

Plough
Comet
Northeast Horizon

It had about the brightness of a
star of the 4th. magnitude,
appearing to the naked eye, as a
blurred spot of light; rather faint,
yet easily visible. In the opera
glasses this blur resolved itself

into a star-like nucleus, a bright
coma, + a short, broad tail. In the
prism binoculars these details were
better seen, whilst in the 3" telescope
with powers of 50 + 100 the comet
was indeed a beautiful sight.
A small telescope star could
at that time be seen shining through
the faint luminosity of the tail.
The best view was with 3" telescopetel.
terrestrialterr. Eyepiece 50 diameters.

Tail about 1 in length.
Observations made from grounds of
residence, + somewhat hampered
by electric street lights.

At this same time Moon was a
beautiful crescent 3daysd. before new.
Earthshine very powerful: Could see
Maria Crisium, SerenitatisSeren. TranquillitatisTranq.
Fcec.Fec.Fecunditatis NectarisNect. very plainly on dark
part of disc.
Schickard on terminator - fine
sight. Grimaldi visible - very dark.
Saturn also fine object.
Winter stars fully in view - Orion,
Canis Major, +c. Orion's nebula
very beautiful in 3" with powerpr. 50

SeptemberSeptr. 17 - ObservedObs. Delavans Comet
4-5 a.m. Also Moon.
Earthshine on Moon very strong,
especially when rising above house top
+ bright thin crescent hidden.
Comet appears brighter as Moon wanes.
Principal Astronomical Work

(1) To keep track of all celestial
phenomena month by month, as
positions of planets, phases of moon,
Sign of Sun, Occultations, Meteor Showers,
unusual phenomena (record)
also new discoveries.

(2) To keep up a working knowledge
of the constellations and their
Seasons.

(3) To observe all planets, etc.
with a large telescope when they
are favourably situated (at 7h 30m
in winter, aboutabt. 9h or lesless in Summer,
supplemented by morning observations)

(4) To observe opera or field glasglass
objects among the stars with a low
power instrument, recording results,

(5) To keep a careful record of
each nights work.

(6) To contribute a monthly
astronomical article of about 7 p. M.S.
or 4 p. type, to the Providence Evening
News. (Began Jan 1, 1914.)
[DEL[UNCLEAR: 88]]

Position of Residence
598 Angell StreetSt., ProvidenceProv., Rhode IslandR.I.

Latitude 41 50' 00" NorthN.
Longitude 71 23' 09" WestW.
locallo. Time 4h 45m 32.3sx
(Washington), locallo. 0h 22m 43.5s#
DifferenceDiff. betweenbetn Mn. + StandardStan. 0h 14m 27.7s (- mn to standardstan)
Fundamental Data

1 LatitudeLat. = 69.23m at 41 50'
1 LongitudeLon. = 52.00m "at "41 50'
1s Time = 1146.5ft "at "41 50'
1 LongitudeLon = (1 LatitudeLat) (cos. LatitudeLat)
Remarks

To red. W.M.T.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Mean_Time to Eastern Standard TimeEast. Stanhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Time_Zone
add 6m 16s. G.M.T.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenwich_Mean_Time to
Eastern Standard TimeE. Stan. Subtract 5h.
# To be added to W.M.T. for Local Time

x To be subtracted from G.M.T.
for Local Time.

Dimensions of Telescope
Clear Aperture ---- 3 inches
Eyepieces, 2. 50 (terrestrialterr) and 125 (astronomicalast.)
Focus (with astronomicalastro.) --- 44in
"Focus ("with terrestrialterr.) --- 52in
ManufacturedManuf. By BardouManufacturer is probably: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Albert_Bardou
AltazimuthAltazimuth mount: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altazimuth_mount Stand by R.L. Allen
Purchased 1906 (Sep. 13)
Accessories
Lunar Map By Wright
Year Book - Farmers AlmanackProbably: Vmtl. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farmers%27_Almanac, cf.: https://www.farmersalmanac.com/
